item.title: Spring
item.dc:creator: @jme jme
item.description:
@jme wrote:

Moparisthebest:

That looks like a great place to live, secluded, and plenty of fishing. Can you hunt around there too? If so, what kind of game?

Almost every time I leave my house I see deer, but I’m no hunter. But everyone I know hunts and most people have hunt camps further in the bush. There is great hunting for deer (mostly 12 pointers at max), moose, bear… Also bird hunting (partridge, turkey, duck, goose…)

SETO:

i am interested in where you got this deal from, point me the way…looking to buy some property near the waterfront, but where i live a condo near the waterfront w/ 2 bedroom costs about 300K

Part of the reason why it’s cheap here,

a) I’m over 20 min away from basic amenities.
b) It’s all dangerous dirt roads here, barely maintained
c) frequent power outages, that can last long
b) If it snows, you can wait up to a day for the snow plough to come

etc, these only scratch some of the reasons why people would pay less to live here. Also, everything is backwards here in quebec. But cheaper too…

Read full topic

item.title: Spring
item.dc:creator: @SETO SETO
item.description:
@SETO wrote:

[quote=“jme, post:12, topic:436985”]Canada has A LOT of water(and not many people). Unless you live in a major city or in western canada, then it`s pretty darn cheap to buy a waterfront. Especially where I live on the ontario-quebec boarder. Theres probably more waterfronts than non-waterfronts

This house is worth under 200k. I didnt really buy it though, im doingrent to ownso I have the option to buy it and I dont have to deal with mortgages etc right now. A portion of my rent goes towards the down-payment.[/quote]

i am interested in where you got this deal from, point me the way…looking to buy some property near the waterfront, but where i live a condo near the waterfront w/ 2 bedroom costs about 300K

Read full topic

item.title: Spring
item.dc:creator: @bowserjr2 Bowser jr
item.description:
@bowserjr2 wrote:

[quote=“R.I.P RSC, post:11, topic:436985”][quote author=Bowser jr link=topic=539701.msg3951486#msg3951486 date=1332327364]
Radeon: It is better to risk being thrown out of your house, than having to pay a rent and not owning anything after n years.
[/quote]

That’s not really in accordance with your socialist/communist ideas, is it?[/quote]
This is a “lesser of two evils” scenario. I think nobody should have to live on other’s ground, and I don’t see how that is against any socialist ideas. Yes, I would remove private property rights in favour of public property rights, so everyone would technically own all the houses and nobody would be forced to the street because they weren’t able to pay the back the money they owe. But people should be able to do the best out of the current situation as long as they don’t exploit others in any ways.

Because the main argument against capitalism from many communists/socialist is the idea of earning money by exploiting others. By borrowing money and buy yourself a house you aren’t doing anything bad.

There is some other problems with private ownership of peoples homes, but that doesn’t applies here.

Read full topic

item.title: Spring
item.dc:creator: @jme jme
item.description:
@jme wrote:

Canada has A LOT of water(and not many people). Unless you live in a major city or in western canada, then it`s pretty darn cheap to buy a waterfront. Especially where I live on the ontario-quebec boarder. Theres probably more waterfronts than non-waterfronts

This house is worth under 200k. I didnt really buy it though, im doingrent to ownso I have the option to buy it and I dont have to deal with mortgages etc right now. A portion of my rent goes towards the down-payment.

Read full topic

item.title: Spring
item.dc:creator: @R.I.P_RSC R.I.P RSC
item.description:
@R.I.P_RSC wrote:

Bowser jr:

Radeon: It is better to risk being thrown out of your house, than having to pay a rent and not owning anything after n years.

That’s not really in accordance with your socialist/communist ideas, is it?

@jme: Nice house, is it in a decent condition or does it need a lot of work? If you don’t mind my asking, what did it cost? You don’t have to be specific, but I’m just wondering how much such a house in Canada would cost. A similar house in perfect condition, in a rural area and close to water would be impossible to buy for someone your age, in the Netherlands.

Read full topic

item.title: Spring
item.dc:creator: @MujaheD Radeon
item.description:
@MujaheD wrote:

Pwnd:

PEOPLE AFFORD HOUSES WITHOUT LOANS? I thought the whole point was to get a loan so you owe someone money for the rest of your life.

Loans make more people afford to buy houses
drives house prices up
less people afford houses
Repeat loop.

If the day comes where you can’t pay your mortgage, banks don’t hesitate to force you and your family to the street just to avoid losing a relatively small amount of money.

Also iirc, mort-gage is Latin for dead pledge

Read full topic
